metadata.title: Examination of rheological behavior of MWCNTs/ZnO-SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants under various temperatures and solid volume fractions

sections.text:
Engine oil is a type of lubricants and coolants that is used in internal combustion engines. In this paper, an examination of viscosity of MWCNTs/ZnO-SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants under various temperatures and solid volume fractions is presented. The experiments performed at temperature ranging from 25 o C to 60 o C and solid volume fractions of 0, 0.05%, 0.075%, 0.1%, 0.2%, 0.4%, 0.5%, 0.75% and 1%. The results revealed that the nano-lubricant behaves as Newtonian fluid. Viscosity measurements also showed that the viscosity decreases with increasing temperature and increases with an enhancement in the solid volume fraction. Using experimental data, relative viscosity indicated that the maximum enhancement of viscosity of the nano-lubricant was 33.3%. This occurred at solid volume fraction of 1.0% and temperature of 40 o C. Based on experimental results, the correlation has been proposed to estimate the viscosity of MWCNTs/ZnO-SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants.
Keywords: Viscosity, Hybrid nano-lubricant, ZnO, MWCNTs, Engine oil, Nanofluid

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
An important type of coolants and lubricants is engine oil, which is used in thermal engines. The main duties of engine oil are to reduce friction in moving parts and engine cooling. For these duties, the thermal conductivity and viscosity are two key parameters in the cooling and lubrication of engines. Since engine oil with enhanced thermal conductivity can increase the rate of heat transfer, engineers are always looking for methods to increase the thermal conductivity. The using of nano-sized materials in common liquid (e.g. water, ethylene glycol and oil), which is called nanofluid, is one of these methods. Many researchers have used metallic nanoparticles to improve thermal conductivity [1-7]. Some researchers also added carbon nanotubes (CNTs) into the base fluid because of their unique thermal properties [8-10]. They showed that adding the nanoparticles intensely enhances the thermal conductivity of nanofluids. However, the dynamic viscosity of the fluids is dramatically altered by the adding nanoparticles to the base fluids. Many researchers investigated the dynamic viscosity of nanofluids [11-20]. They showed that the viscosity of nanofluids is a function of temperature, concentration and size of nanoparticles. They also proposed the empirical correlations for estimating the viscosity of nanofluids. In the mentioned studies, the measured viscosities of nanofluids were compared with existing well-known models. One of the well-known known models was introduced by Batchelor [21]. He presented a correlation to estimate the viscosity of nanofluids with spherical shape nanoparticles which is given as:
 22.65.21

Moreover, the well-known Einstein correlation for predicting viscosity of nanofluids with spherical particles was proposed by Drew and Passman [22] and is known as follows:

Furthermore, Wang et al. [23] suggested a model for estimating the viscosity of nanofluids which is expressed as:

In Eqs. (1)-(3), µ is the dynamic viscosity,  is the solid volume fraction, and d is the
diameter of nanoparticles in nm. Moreover, the subscripts of nf, bf and p indicate respectively nanofluid, base fluid and particle. µr is defined as the ratio of the dynamic viscosity of nanofluid to dynamic viscosity of base fluid. In recent decade, there has been attention for the use of hybrid nanofluids. Many researches have been experimentally performed regarding the properties of these nanofluids. For example, thermo-physical properties of hybrid nanofluids such as Cu/Al2O3-water [24], MWCNT/SiO2-water [25], Cu/Cu2O-water [26], MWCNT/Ag-water [27], Ag/TiO2-water [28], MWCNT/Fe2O3-water [29], Cu/TiO2-water [30], Ag/MgO-water [31], Fe3O4/Ag-EG [32], DWCNT/ZnO-EG/water [33], MWCNTs/SiO2-EG/water [34], and CNTs/Al2O3-water [35] have been investigated. Because of several applications of engine oils, these have attracted the interest of researchers. In this regard, Vakili-Nezhaad et al. [36] investigated the effect of MWCNTs on the viscosity index of lube oil cuts. Vasheghani et al. [37] examined the effect of Al2O3 phases on the enhancement of thermal conductivity and viscosity of nanofluids in engine oil. Ettefaghi et al. [38, 39] investigated thermal and rheological properties of oil-based nanofluids from different carbon nanostructures. Recently, Afrand et al. [40] examined the effects of temperature and concentration of
SiO2/MWCNTs hybrid nanomaterials on the viscosity of engine oil (SAE40). Their results indicated that the maximum enhancement of viscosity of the hybrid nanofluid was 37.4%. Based on the review of previous works, it was observed that many researchers measured the dynamic viscosity of nanofluids containing various kinds of metal or nonmetal nanoparticles. Moreover, only a few works have been performed on thermo-physical properties of engine oils. However, the MWCNTs/ZnO-SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricant has not been investigated. In this paper, the dynamic viscosity of MWCNTs/ZnO-SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricant is examined at various solid volume fractions under different temperature. Moreover, a new correlation is suggested to predict the dynamic viscosity of MWCNTs/ZnO-SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricant.

sections.heading: 2.1. Nanofluid preparation
sections.text:
The first step for the experimentations is the preparation of nano-lubricant samples. In order to ensure the appropriate dispersion, proper mechanisms such as mixing and sonication can be used. In this work, solid particles, which were composed of 10% volume of MWCNT and 90% volume ZnO, were dispersed in engine oil (SAE40). The specifications of MWCNTs and ZnO, purchased from US-nanomaterials Company, are presented in Table 1. In order to achieve a characterization of the sample, the structural properties of the dry MWCNTs and ZnO nanoparticles were measured by using X-ray diffraction as shown in Fig. 1. A two-step method was used to prepare the nanofluid samples (0, 0.05%, 0.075%, 0.1%, 0.2%, 0.4%, 0.5%, 0.75% and 1% vol.). The amounts of nanoparticles and engine oil for preparing the samples are presented Table 2. In the present experiment, for preparing stable samples, after magnetic stirring for 1h, the samples were exposed to an ultrasonic
processor of KND-1200-UH1 with power of 1200 W for 8h. In order to prevent a rise in temperature during the sonication process, a thermocouple was attached to ultrasonic device, which kept the temperature under 50 o C. Visual observations showed that nanofluid samples exhibit good stability after 21 days and no obvious sedimentation is observed. The photograph of all samples is displayed in Fig. 2.

sections.heading: 2.2. Dynamic viscosity measurement
sections.text:
In order to measure the viscosity of MWCNTs/ZnO-SAE40, a CAP 2000+ Viscometer (Brookfield-USA) was employed. The Viscometer is medium to high shear rate device with Cone-Plate geometry and joined temperature control of the test sample. Measurements were performed at the temperature range of 25-50 o C and the shear rate range of 1333-13333s -1 . The range of accuracy and repeatability of the Viscometer are respectively ±2.0% and ±0.5% of the full scale range (FSR). Before the measurement of dynamic viscosity of
nanofluids, the viscometer was tested by glycerin at 300K. The viscosity of glycerin is 950centipoise, while it was obtained 922.2centipoise from the CAP 2000+ Viscometer. Therefore, there was error of 2.93%.
Fig. 1. XRD pattern for MWCNTs and ZnO nanoparticles
All experiments were repeated at different shear rates for each solid volume fraction and temperature to make sure its repeatability, and then the average of measured data was recorded.
Fig. 4 depicts shear stress versus shear rate for nano-lubricant at solid volume fraction of 1% and temperature of 25 o C. It can be found that MWCNT/ZnO-SAE40 hybrid nanolubricant behaves as Newtonian fluid.
Fig. 4. Shear stress versus shear rate for hybrid nano-lubricant at φ=1% and T=25 o C.
Fig. 5 shows the dynamic viscosity of nano-lubricant at different temperatures. It can be seen that the viscosity of the nano-lubricant increases with solid volume fraction. Viscosity is a property occurring from collisions between particles in a fluid that have a velocity difference. In fact, it is due to the van der Waals forces between the liquid molecules. Hence, the suspending nanoparticles into SAE40 would raise its viscosity as a result of the collisions between nanoparticles and the base fluid. By growing the amount of solid nanoparticles in a constant amount of a liquid, greater nano-racemes arise due to van der Waals forces. These nano- racemes hamper the motion of oil layers on each other, leading to an upper increase in viscosity. As can be seen in Fig. 5, at lower temperatures, viscosity increment is more sensible than that at higher temperature. In fact, at lower temperatures, the nano-racemes, which prevent the motion of oil layers on each other, are due to the very strong van der Waals interactions between particles. This phenomenon increases the viscosity intensely. This increase is smoother than that of at higher temperatures. This is
because the fact that increasing temperature helps the particles to overcome the attractive van der Waals forces.
Fig. 5. Dynamic viscosity versus solid volume fraction at different temperatures.
For the understanding of viscosity variation with temperature, the dynamic viscosity versus temperature at different solid volume fractions is demonstrated in Fig. 6. The results reveal that the viscosity of the nano-lubricant decreases with increasing temperature with a similar trend. This is due to the fact that, with increasing temperature, the intermolecular interactions between the molecules become weak and therefore the viscosity decreases.
Fig. 6. Dynamic viscosity versus temperature at different solid volume fractions.
The effects of temperature and solid volume fraction on relative viscosity of nano-lubricant are illustrated in Fig. 7. It is clear that the maximum enhancement of viscosity of MWCNTs/ZnO-SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants is 33.3%. This occurred at solid volume fraction of 1.0% and temperature of 40 o C. The reason may be related to the fact that at higher volume fractions (e.g. 1%), the nanoparticles clustering is more probable. At solid volume fraction of 1% and temperature of 40 o C, the nanoparticles clustering reaches its climax. Then, by increasing the temperature, these clusters are broken as a result of reduced van der Waals force. This phenomenon causes the decrease in relative viscosity.
Fig. 7. Effects of temperature and solid volume fraction on relative viscosity of nano-lubricant.

sections.heading: 4. Proposing a new correlation
sections.text:

Fig. 8 shows a comparison between experimental and predicted values. Moreover this figure illustrates the measured margin of deviation for all experiments. It can be seen that the maximum margin of deviation is ±2%. Figs. Fig. 8 shows a good agreement between the experimental and predicted data.
Fig. 8. Comparison between experimental and predicted values.
In order to show the margin of deviation at each experimental value, Fig. 9 is presented. It can be seen that in most points, the experimental data and correlation outputs overlap each other. This behavior reveals that suggested correlation has a good accuracy.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion
sections.text:
In the present work, examination of viscosity of MWCNTs/ZnO-SAE40 hybrid nanolubricants under various temperatures (25°C to 50°C) and solid volume fraction ranging from 0 to 1% has been performed. The results revealed that the nano-lubricant behaves as Newtonian fluid. Viscosity measurements also showed that the viscosity decreases with
increasing temperature and increases with an enhancement in the solid volume fraction. Using experimental data, relative viscosity indicated that the maximum enhancement of viscosity of the nano-lubricant was 33.3%. This occurred at solid volume fraction of 1.0% and temperature of 40 o C. Based on experimental results, the correlation has been proposed to estimate the viscosity of MWCNTs/ZnO-SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants. Maximum value of deviation was ±2%. Comparison between the experimental data and the correlation outputs indicated that the suggested model has an acceptable accuracy.

It can be observed that Einstein [22] and Wang [23] models are not suitable for predicting the viscosity of MWCNTs/ZnO-SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants.

metadata.abstractText: Engine oil is a type of lubricants and coolants that is used in internal combustion engines. In this paper, an examination of viscosity of MWCNTs/ZnO-SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants under various temperatures and solid volume fractions is presented. The experiments performed at temperature ranging from 25 o C to 60 o C and solid volume fractions of 0, 0.05%, 0.075%, 0.1%, 0.2%, 0.4%, 0.5%, 0.75% and 1%. The results revealed that the nano-lubricant behaves as Newtonian fluid. Viscosity measurements also showed that the viscosity decreases with increasing temperature and increases with an enhancement in the solid volume fraction. Using experimental data, relative viscosity indicated that the maximum enhancement of viscosity of the nano-lubricant was 33.3%. This occurred at solid volume fraction of 1.0% and temperature of 40 o C. Based on experimental results, the correlation has been proposed to estimate the viscosity of MWCNTs/ZnO-SAE40 hybrid nano-lubricants.
